Title: Zabrekalrek, The Black Mountain Saga: Part One

Author: Written by Gorrek Tale-Writer, translated by Hargrid Men-Speaker.


There are many holds in the Eretz built by the Mountain-Kin, but few were as mighty as Zabrekalrek- The Black Mountain. Rumored to be made from first-kin, it was known to be a grand home built from a blackened rock found deep in the core of Eretz. It was where the Dwarves learned the answer to the riddle of steel, and where massive forges billowed dae and nite; creating bars of dark-blue metals. These metals would be shaped into many things; from mighty blades and armor, to even menial eating utensils and toys.


For a time, it was good.


But soon the hold would rumble- Creating massive quakes in the many tunnels and passages in Zabrekalrek. Eventually, the quakes shook even the great throne of the King Khazun III; to which he traveled with his greatest allies to the deepest pit of the black mountain-- where his kin had found the miracle rock. To the King's surprise, it spoke to him:


"THOU HATH PARTAKETH MINE FLESH LONG ENOUGH, CHILDREN OF ERETZ."


Bewildered, Khazun rubbed his weary eyes in shock. A rock that talks? thought the wise Dwarf-king. His company stood in silence as well; utterly terrified of the booming voice. He tried to open his mouth to speak, but before words could pass his lips the great rock spoke again:


"THOU SHALT NOT SPEAK BEFORE ME, WHOMST HATH GRANTED THEE SUCH SUCCOR. THOU SHALT BEND THY KNEE TO GRAGGAR, WHOMST YOU GLANCE UPON!" 


The Dwarf-king did as the rock told; as did his loyal companions. The rock transformed before their eyes into a star-like pattern, with a grimacing face staring back at the Dwarves. Graggar glared with his red eyes, it's terrifying visage was enough to even make the most stubborn goat flee in fear...


"THOU SHALT BEND THY KNEE IN SERVITUDE FOR THY GIFTS, SMALL-DWARF-THINGS. OR PERISH. THOU SHALT WORSHIP ME AS THY OWN GODS."


King Khazun, lord of Zabrekalrek, could not abide by such demands... And replied:


"No."


Then, the mountain erupted.
